articles.headline: 2-Year College, Squeezed, Sets 2-Tier Tuition
articles.snippet: Santa Monica College, in California, will offer some courses for a higher price, so that students who are eager to get into a particular class can do so if they pay more.
articles.abstract: Santa Monica College, in California, will offer some courses for a higher price, so that students who are eager to get into a particular class can do so if they pay more.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — For years now, administrators at the community college here have been inundated with woeful tales from students unable to register for the courses they need. Classes they want for essential job training or to fulfill requirements to transfer to four-year universities fill up within hours. Hundreds of students resort to crying and begging to enroll in a class, lining up at the doors of instructors and academic counselors.

articles.headline: Electronic Giant Vowing Reforms in China Plants
articles.snippet: Responding to a critical investigation of its factories, Foxconn, a top electronics supplier for Apple and other companies, pledged to curtail working hours and increase wages.
articles.abstract: Responding to a critical investigation of its factories, Foxconn, a top electronics supplier for Apple and other companies, pledged to curtail working hours and increase wages.
articles.lead_paragraph: Responding to a critical investigation of its factories, the manufacturing giant Foxconn has pledged to sharply curtail working hours and significantly increase wages inside Chinese plants making electronic products for Apple and others. The move could improve working conditions across China.
articles.byline: By Charles Duhigg and Steven Greenhouse

articles.headline: A Tax on Snacks Aggravates Austerity Tensions in Britain
articles.snippet: A plan to impose a tax on hot take-away food while lowering income taxes on millionaires brings back memories of other unpopular measures imposed by the government.
articles.abstract: A plan to impose a tax on hot take-away food while lowering income taxes on millionaires brings back memories of other unpopular measures imposed by the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — George Osborne, the posh chancellor of the Exchequer, confesses he cannot recall the last time he partook of a pasty, the calorie-busting savory pastry, served hot, that is beloved by millions of average Britons.

articles.headline: Panel Recommends More Testing for Obesity Drugs
articles.snippet: An advisory panel of the F.D.A. said obesity drugs should get extra testing to ensure against heart attacks and strokes.
articles.abstract: An advisory panel of the F.D.A. said obesity drugs should get extra testing to ensure against heart attacks and strokes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Obesity drugs should undergo clinical trials to ensure that they do not cause heart attacks, federal advisers said Thursday, a requirement that could make it harder for such drugs to gain approval.

articles.headline: A Strategy to Vote Dead Shares
articles.snippet: Emmis Communications is pursuing a plan to strip its preferred shares of their rights and to never pay another dividend for those shares again.
articles.abstract: Emmis Communications is pursuing a plan to strip its preferred shares of their rights and to never pay another dividend for those shares again.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was an old joke in which a man said that when he died he hoped to be buried in Chicago, so that he could continue to vote.

articles.headline: In Hollywood, an ’80s Moment
articles.snippet: At a time of plunging DVD sales and an up-and-down box office, Hollywood is doubling back on past hits, like “Dirty Dancing,” and stars like Bette Midler and Arnold Schwarzenegger.
articles.abstract: At a time of plunging DVD sales and an up-and-down box office, Hollywood is doubling back on past hits, like “Dirty Dancing,” and stars like Bette Midler and Arnold Schwarzenegger.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “21 Jump Street” is a hit. “RoboCop” and “Dirty Dancing” are on the way. Arnold Schwarzenegger is juggling a bunch of action flicks.

articles.headline: Case Based in China Puts a Face on Persistent Hacking
articles.snippet: A breach of computers belonging to companies in Japan and India and to Tibetan activists has been linked to a former student at a Chinese university.
articles.abstract: A breach of computers belonging to companies in Japan and India and to Tibetan activists has been linked to a former student at a Chinese university.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A breach of computers belonging to companies in Japan and India and to Tibetan activists has been linked to a former graduate student at a Chinese university — putting a face on the persistent espionage by Chinese hackers against foreign companies and groups.

articles.headline: In Hiding, Bin Laden Had Four Children and Five Houses
articles.snippet: Testimony by Osama bin Laden’s youngest wife has offered the most detailed account yet of the family’s life on the run preceding the raid in May 2011 that killed the Qaeda leader.
articles.abstract: Testimony by Osama bin Laden’s youngest wife has offered the most detailed account yet of the family’s life on the run preceding the raid in May 2011 that killed the Qaeda leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Osama bin Laden spent nine years on the run in Pakistan after the Sept. 11 attacks, during which time he moved among five safe houses and fathered four children, at least two of whom were born in a government hospital, his youngest wife has told Pakistani investigators.

articles.headline: U.S. and China Press for Influence in Myanmar
articles.snippet: As strategically placed Myanmar loosens the grip of dictatorship, each side is doing whatever it can to gain the country’s favor.
articles.abstract: As strategically placed Myanmar loosens the grip of dictatorship, each side is doing whatever it can to gain the country’s favor.
articles.lead_paragraph: HSIPAW, Myanmar — As Chinese workers in hard hats and red overalls bulldoze deep trenches into the orange soil across northern Myanmar for gas and oil pipelines to China, China’s largest energy conglomerate is paying cash for land and trees in the pipelines’ path, and building schools and health clinics for some of the poorest people on earth.

articles.headline: In Health Case, Appeals to a Justice’s Idea of Liberty
articles.snippet: In making their arguments to the Supreme Court about the health law, advocates tried to win over Justice Anthony M. Kennedy by invoking one of his most valued principles: liberty.
articles.abstract: In making their arguments to the Supreme Court about the health law, advocates tried to win over Justice Anthony M. Kennedy by invoking one of his most valued principles: liberty.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The way to frame a Supreme Court argument meant to persuade Justice Anthony M. Kennedy is to talk about liberty. It is his touchstone and guiding principle, and his conception of liberty is likely to determine the future of President Obama’s health care law.

articles.headline: In Europe, Starbucks Adjusts to a Cafe Culture
articles.snippet: The coffeehouse chain is embarking on a multimillion-dollar campaign to win over Europe’s coffee aficionados with an upscale makeover of hundreds of stores.
articles.abstract: The coffeehouse chain is embarking on a multimillion-dollar campaign to win over Europe’s coffee aficionados with an upscale makeover of hundreds of stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — On a recent sunny morning in this city’s chic Marais district, Marion Bayod squeezed behind a tiny table at Le Cactus, a neighborhood cafe she has frequented for years. She cast a sidelong glance at a Starbucks across the street.

articles.headline: Broccoli Mandates and the Commerce Clause
articles.snippet: If the Supreme Court limits the commerce clause in striking down the health care law, it could have unintended consequences on Congress’s ability to legislate.
articles.abstract: If the Supreme Court limits the commerce clause in striking down the health care law, it could have unintended consequences on Congress’s ability to legislate.
articles.lead_paragraph: “If the government can do this, what, what else can it not do?” asked Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia this week in arguments on the constitutionality of the requirement that nearly all Americans buy health care insurance or face a penalty.
